reviewText:
A good chunk of my early play time with Supercharged Robot Vulkaiser was spent with a grin on my face. As someone who‚Äôs watched his fair share of old Japanese cartoons, it really is a well observed little thing. From the slightly cheap looking splash screens, the pompy music, even the loading screens and level title cards, it‚Äôs chock full of character. Then there‚Äôs the game itself, you‚Äôre a giant red robot who can fire his fists like missiles and combine with his co-pilots like Power Rangers.

It‚Äôs not all just for colour either, which pilot you combine with affects your type of attack. Take Rocket Kaiser for example, combine with him and your shots will be accompanied by powerful missiles, with the charged weapon essentially being a huge bomb, great for taking down powerful enemies, but a spread of enemies could easily swarm you. In that case you‚Äôd be better off with Needle Kaiser, a wide shot type, but she‚Äôs weak both in terms of armour and damage dealt. Drill Kaiser is hugely powerful, but her range is tiny, meaning you‚Äôre putting yourself in danger every time you attack. Thunder Kaiser is something of a mix, his standard attack has decent range, his charge shot is powerful, but his bomb is feeble

Supercharged Robot Vulkaiser has a peculiar kind of difficulty, the most notable thing is that it must be beaten on a single credit, there‚Äôs no continues to be had. Playing on the easy difficulty I‚Äôve raced to the end of the game, once not even really trying whilst capturing our First Play video. The step up to the next difficulty level though made me hit a wall I‚Äôve struggled to get past. I‚Äôm not sure what it is that‚Äôs stopping me from getting better at the game, it could just be that I‚Äôm not the gamer I used to be. I do sometimes feel a bit blind to the incoming bullets, but no more than any other shooter, but I think it‚Äôs actually more to do with the shame of Vulkaiser. Your hitpoint is fairly small, still easy to hit, but only a tiny part of your giant mech, but because you‚Äôre essentially controlling a giant line whilst looking at the enemy, it‚Äôs very easy to drag it in to incoming fire.

Supercharged Robot Vulkaiser is a little sparse in terms of modes. There‚Äôs the story mode and ‚Äòtraining‚Äô, which is just the main missions there for you to retry. I‚Äôm not sure Supercharged Robot Vulkaiser is the game to spend hours practising, learning patterns. The training mode does allow you to complete stages though, opening up the next one you couldn‚Äôt reach in a single run. It‚Äôs not a bad way to see the later levels on the harder difficulties, which at least helps keep things interesting. If you are chasing score then it does separate them by difficulty, and I think the scoring system works by rewarding you for destroying enemies as quickly as possible as they appear on screen, so maybe there is something to be said for spending the time learning patterns.

In terms of presentation, the game has no resolution options. As soon as you hit play though you‚Äôre presented with the option to go full screen, which may seem like a small thing, and does cause some problems on a 2 screen set up, as it merely changes your resolution to match the game‚Äôs. It‚Äôs welcome though, we‚Äôve reviewed a couple of games in the past year or so that haven‚Äôt had that option. One of the drawbacks though, and this is kind of funny if you‚Äôre not playing seriously, is it means that when you unlock an achievement, or a friend signs in to Steam, you can‚Äôt see a third of the screen. So if you are planning a serious run at the game, maybe turn off notifications.

There‚Äôs no doubting Supercharged Robot Vulkaiser is fun, but a lot of that comes from its charm. It does a great job of harking back to old-school anime, both in tone and theme. I‚Äôm less sure the game itself rates as highly or holds up to repeated playthroughs. Which is a shame, I really like the mecha gimmick of combining with the other pilots, and their strengths and weaknesses do add a level of strategy to the game, it‚Äôs just a shame the level design doesn‚Äôt build on it, instead feeling more like a shooting gallery. Still, for the price it‚Äôs a fun bit of nostalgia, hard to dislike, and not something you‚Äôll have seen too often

reviewText:
Supercharged Robot Vulkaiser is a really fun game even though I'm not too big of side scrolling bullet genre. As a big mecha fan I really enjoyed the homages to the different super robots of the 70s with their bright colours and funny looking enemy designs. That being said the game itself is quite short but that doesn't stop it from being fun.

The game consists of four levels of difficulty and the option of playing the launch mode straight away or practice mode where you can access all six levels and get used to the level before trying it on the launch mode. An interesting feature with this game is that bullets are able to hit your hands and feet without you taking any damage, Vulkaiser's chest is your hitbox and as long as it doesn't hit an enemy blast you won't lose health.

You have the option to combine with four different types of support units or face the enemies alone with the base Vulkaiser and its rocket fists. Be careful though, if your support unit is destroyed during a stage it cannot be repaired. My personal favorite is the Lightning unit since it can clear mass swarms of enemies and is great for boss fights.

Some things that the game can add to make it better include:
-A pause button, something that can really help since you're forced to play the whole six levels in one go.
-An options menu, this is a big one since there's no guide to the control keys. Luckily I played the Satazius demo and learned the keys from that but if I went in blind, I'd be absolutely lost in terms of controls.
-Additional levels or the choice to choose levels after being defeated. Whilst the game is short it is a bit frustrating to hit the last boss and be forced back to the first level and go through everything again before getting back to the boss.


I'm a big mecha fan and if you enjoy side shooters and giant robots then this game is for you. It's short and sweet but something about it makes me want to keep shooting away at hordes of enemy robots and their retro design.

reviewText:
The retro styled Supercharged Robot VULKAISER with it's 2d side scrolling shootem up wins hands down.

The story is very minimal, but can have minor changes based on which powerups you used, but none of this affects the primary story line. The other characters have minimal parts, but the real charm about SRV, is how classic and simple it is.

Fly through levels and defeat both mini-bosses and regular bosses with your Vulkaiser. Bits of mini dialogue have it stand out from your typical side scrolling shooter, and will likely remind you of super giant robot sized mecha anime of the past.

With variable difficulty from easy to super hard, this game can go from a casual shooter that still challenges to a wicked hard bullet hell that will keep you trying again and again.

With a price tag of about $5, the game is actually well worth it. It has replayability due to the multiple achievements and the different dialogues between stages.

The one negative is that it is a little short, but the developers have recently stepped up and addressed community issues, fixing their concerns.

Overall, I'd give Supercharged Robot VULKAISER an 8 out of 10.

Challenging even on the easiest difficulty setting, and sometimes punishingly so, given how you only get partial repairs between stages and if a module gets destroyed, it's gone for good.\nFun if you like bullet hell style games and giant robots with the 70s and 80s mix of cheesy, over the top and ludicrous fun, but it suffers from a lack of options. A great little arcade shooter well worth the asking price. Supercharged Robot Vulkaiser is a short bullet hell shooter that parodies the 70s giant robot anime genre. Vulkaiser only has five levels but it's an addictive game with great presentation and replay value. You take control of the titular Vulkaiser and it's pilot Takuya Akatsuki dodging bullets and blasting waves of enemies as you defend earth from androgynous alien invader General Roz. Vulkaiser can combine with four other vehicles developed by Professor Amamori and piloted by Takuya's allies, each one offering Vulkaiser new attacks, knowing when to choose which unit becomes part of Vulkaiser's strategy as you deal with the varying threats the alien menace poses.\n\nThis is a great indy title from Japanese developer Astro Port and at it's budget price can't afford to be missed, arcade gamers and bullet hell fans alike will love it. definitely pick it up.

I'm a fan of all of Astro Port's games on Steam (Satazius, Gigantic Army, Armed Seven), and this one is no exception. In fact, it might be my favorite of the bunch. It nails the 70s anime aesthetic, is self-aware enough to laugh with and not at, and the shooting action is superb. This is how I remember my favorite 16-bit shooters feeling.

Yes, it lacks options. It could use customizable controls (or at the very least, a screen that shows you the controls, period!), screen resolution settings, saving, pausing... none of that is here. For some, that might be a deal-breaker. But it's so much fun that I can look past those flaws. It's pure arcade joy.

A sidescrolling SHMUP in the vein of 1970's SUPER ROBOT mecha anime. WITH YELLOW SUBTITLES!

It's pretty gawd-dammed perfect as far as what it sets out to do. You shoot all of the the things while bombastic music plays in the background facing a recurring miniboss and so many enemies that are obvious references to the tatsunoko era of anime. It's very self-aware and pretty glorious.

Best of all, there's actually some interesting design choices for the genre, so you'll actually find a different gameplay experience here. Namely in the health system. Rather than being a 1HP hero, you have a fairly meaty health bar, but it carries over from stage to stage and only gets some repairs between stages. Moreover, your co-pilot partners who act as your powerups also have their own, much smaller, health bars and just like in Star Fox they can get KO'd for good if you're too careless through the short 30 minute campaign.

Plus, rather than a whole bunch of bombs in a stage like most shoot 'em ups, you only get one OMEGA BOMB per stage to use when the going gets tough, so strategic deployment of both your team mates and when you pull out your super move is actually fairly critical.

And it's all executed flawlessly. Literally the only complaint I have is that the video used to sell the game with the sung VULKAISER themesong isn't actually in the game. If it was it'd be 110% perfect!

As it is, I'll just settle for 100% perfect.

Supercharged Robot VULKAISER is a game where you take on the role of a supercharged robot which is allegedly named Vulkaiser. Now that we've gotten the obvious out of the way...

Basically, you're in a mech suit, you fly around a screen, and you shoot lots of lasers, bullets, lightening, and a couple other things at a bunch of other mech suits and spaceships. It's a callback to games like Gradius, where the enemies come in specific waves, ending in a boss battle. Repeat the formula two or three times, and you have yourself an entire level. Repeat that formula a couple dozen times, and you have the game I'm currently reviewing.

This is not to suggest the game falls short of entertaining. I got it in a Humble Bundle with a dollar donation, so I can't really complain, but it's not often I find something I'll actually play again in the veritable bin of indie games available on humble bundle. This game shakes up combat by offering you an upgrade every so often, which will augment your current robot into something with better weapons, which is cool. Boss designs are pretty interesting, and the music is intense enough to help gameplay, and simple enough to not distract. Controls feel pretty good, and combat feels natural - well, natural if you're a supercharged robot vulkaiser. You could do a lot worse.
